questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the condition shown in the image below which is seen in a 2-month-old child with stridor.

choices.text: There is excessive flacidity of supraglottic larynx.
Flexible laryngoscopes are useful in diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis in a child with stridor, suggesting the diagnosis of laryngomalacia. The arytenoids are prominent in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.  It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows -

  • Elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped)
  • Floppy aryepiglottic folds, and 
  • Prominent arytenoids 

A flexible laryngoscope is very useful to make the diagnosis. Laryngomalacia cannot be visualized in a paralyzed patient.

Treatment:

  • conservative in most cases
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

The below image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis.

questions.text: The lateral view neck x-ray of a 65-year-old male patient showed the presence of a foreign body in the larynx. You suspect that it may represent calcification of one of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of the following cartilages is most likely to undergo calcification mimicking the laryngeal foreign body?
questions.solution:
The cricoid cartilage undergoes calcification, which may mimic a foreign body on x-ray.

Only hyaline cartilage can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It mostly is seen at the age of 25–65 years. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of the esophagus or larynx on x-rays.

Hyaline laryngeal cartilages:

  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Most of the arytenoid cartilage

Elastic laryngeal cartilages:

  • Epiglottic cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Tip of the arytenoid cartilage

Related Pearl: Cartilages of Larynx

Unpaired Cartilages
Paired Cartilages
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Epiglottis
  • Arytenoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform

 

Hyaline
Fibroelastic

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient comes to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the left ear. Rinne’s test shows bone conduction is better than air conduction. Weber test shows lateralization towards the left ear. The absolute bone conduction test is normal. What will be the inference of Schwabach's test in this patient?

choices.text: Lengthened as compared to the examiner
Shortened as compared to the examiner
Same as compared to the examiner
Difficult to interpret with the given data

questions.solution:
The patient here complains of hearing loss. Rinne's test showing BC>AC in the left ear, Weber's test lateralizing to the left ear, and a normal ABC test are suggestive of conductive deafness in his left ear. Schwabach’s test is lengthened in conductive deafness.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration, while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

In Schwabach's test, the bone conduction of the patient is compared with that of the examiner, but unlike the absolute bone conduction test, the EAC is not occluded. Inferences are as follows:

  • Normal: The test result is the same as that of the examiner
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is lengthier than that of the examiner
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is shorter than that of the examiner

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus(EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive(normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15 - 20 dB.

Weber's test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound is heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worst ear.
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear.

In the absolute bone conduction(ABC) test, the patient’s bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner after occluding (by pressing the tragus inwards) EAC of both the patient and the examiner to prevent the ambient noise from entering through the AC route. It is used to assess cochlear deafness.

  • Normal result: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Conductive deafness: The test result is the same as the examiner.
  • Sensorineural deafness: The test result is reduced to that of the examiner.

Note: The ABC test and Schwabach's test are done assuming the hearing of the examiner is normal.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: A boy presents with complaints of intermittent low-grade fever and membrane over the left tonsil, which appeared insidiously. On examination of the oral cavity, the surgeon tried to remove the membrane, which came off easily revealing an irregular ulcer over the tonsil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of low-grade fever, easily removable membrane over tonsil revealing irregular ulcers is suggestive of Vincent’s angina.

The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, specifically Borrelia vincentii.

Other Options:

Option A: Diphtheria is slower in onset with less local discomfort. In the above case, the membrane is removed easily but in diphtheria, the membrane is adherent and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils, onto the soft palate, and is dirty grey in color. The smear and culture of the throat swab will reveal Corynebacterium diphtheriae.


Option C: In Infectious mononucleosis, pharyngitis is the most prominent sign, with an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. Both tonsils are very much enlarged, congested, and covered with an exudative membrane. There is marked local discomfort. Lymph nodes are enlarged in the posterior triangle of the neck along with splenomegaly. There is the failure of antibiotic treatment. A blood smear may show more than 50% lymphocytes, of which about 10% are atypical. Paul-Bunnell test will show high tires of heterophile antibody.

Option D: Aphthous ulcer are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They may involve any part of the oral cavity or oropharynx. Sometimes, it is solitary and may involve the tonsil and the pillars. It is very painful. 

Other differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsil:

  • Membranous tonsillitis
  • Malignancy of tonsil
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Leukemia
  • Traumatic ulcer
  • Candidal infection of the tonsil

questions.text:
Which of the following blood vessels does not contribute to the blood supply of the organ marked in the below image?
  1. Internal carotid artery
  2. External carotid artery
  3. Facial artery
  4. Lingual artery
  5. Maxillary artery
questions.solution:
The organ marked in the image is the palatine tonsil and the internal carotid artery does not contribute to the blood supply of the palatine tonsil.

Blood supply of the faucial/palatine tonsils:

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery).
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery.
  • Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery.

Venous drainage: Veins from the tonsils drain into the paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve palsy is most common in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
V cranial nerve palsy is the most common palsy seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma usually originates from the nasopharynx in the fossa of Rossenmuller. It is most commonly seen in Chinese people. 

Important etiological factors include Ebstein Barr virus (EBV) infection, tobacco smoking, dry salted fish, and incense fumes.

It presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal- Nasal obstruction due to blockage of the choana or the nasal cavity, denasal speech, nasal discharge, epistaxis.
  • Otologic- Obstruction of the eustachian tube leads to unilateral conductive hearing loss, serous or suppurative otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmologic- These symptoms occur due to the involvement of cranial nerves.
    • Facial pain and reduced corneal reflex- cranial nerve V. This is the most common cranial nerve to be involved.
    • Squint and diplopia- involvement of cranial nerve VI. 
    • Exophthalmos and blindness- cranial nerve II.
    • Horner's syndrome can occur due to involvement of sympathetic chain.
  • Cervical node metastasis- Usually between the angle of jaw and the mastoid. Cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Distant metastasis- to bone, liver, lung, etc.
  • Constitutional symptoms - weight loss.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can cause,

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

This is collectively called as Trotter’s triad.

Enlarged lateral retropharyngeal nodes compresses the cranial nerve IX, X, and XI causing jugular foramen syndrome.

High resolution contrast-enhanced CT (HR-CECT) of nose and nasopharynx is the investigation of choice.

The treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Radiotherapy for stages I and II.
  • Radiotherapy + chemotherapy for stages III and IV.
  • Radical neck dissection can be done in case of recurrent or residual disease.

Other options:

A) Involvement of VI cranial nerve leads to squint and diplopia.

B) Involvement of X cranial nerve leads to palatal paralysis

D) Involvement of IX cranial nerve forms a component of jugular foramen syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in adductor dysphonia?
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is an abductor muscle and is not involved in adductor type of spasmodic dysphonia.

There are 3 types of spasmodic dysphonia:

Adductor dysphonia:

The vocal cords remain in adduction because of the spasm of adductor muscles of the larynx, which are

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid
  • Thyroarytenoid and
  • Interarytenoid

This leads to straining or breaking of voice. Flexible fibreoptic laryngoscopy is useful for diagnosis. One should exclude neurological conditions such as Parkinsonism, myoclonus, pseudobulbar palsy, multiple sclerosis, cerebellar disorders, tardive dyskinesia, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis before commencing therapy using CT/MRI scans. 

Treatment:

  • Botulinum toxin injection in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve spasm
  • Voice therapy to improve voice
  • In severe refractory cases, resection of recurrent laryngeal nerve to paralyze the vocal cords is done

 

Abductor dysphonia:

The posterior cricoarytenoid, the only abductor undergoes spasm thereby keeping the glottis open. The patient may have a breathy voice which bets aggravated during stress or when the patient uses the telephone.

Treatment:

  • To relieve spasms, botulinum toxin injection in the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle
  • Speech therapy
  • In refractory cases, thyroplasty type I or fat injection can be tried

Mixed dysphonia:

It has both adductor and abductor components of spasmodic dysphonia.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text:
Match the following signs and the diseases in which they occur.
Signs Diseases
  1. Hennebert's sign
  2. Schwartz sign
  3. Hitzelberger sign
  4. Bryce's sign
  1. Laryngocele
  2. Congenital syphilis
  3. Otosclerosis
  4. Acoustic neuroma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a.

1 - Hennebert's sign in congenital syphilis

Hennebert's sign is a positive fistula sign (nystagmus occurring on applying positive and negative pressure in the external auditory canal) in the absence of a fistula seen in congenital syphilis due to the formation of adhesions between stapes footplate and saccule. It is also seen in a few cases of Meniere's disease.

This is not to be confused with Hennebert's phenomenon which is disequilibrium following nose blowing or lifting a heavy object. It is seen in the perilymph fistula.

2 - Schwartz sign in otosclerosis

A pink or reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartz sign. It is seen in active otosclerosis.

The image below shows the Schwartz sign.

3 - Hitzelberger sign in acoustic neuroma

Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (supplied by the VII cranial nerve) is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is due to the involvement of the VII cranial nerve in acoustic neuroma.

4 - Bryce's sign in laryngocele

The gurgling sound produced on pressing the swelling in the laryngocele is known as Bryce's sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the surgery in which the following instrument is used?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a myringotome and myringotomy/tympanostomy is done by a sharp myringotome. An intratympanic glomus tumor is a contraindication for myringotomy.

Myringotomy refers to the incision made on the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of a malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of myringotomy:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the Eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital complaining of reduced hearing in the right ear. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. All of the following are uses of this instrument except?

choices.text: To determine the degree of hearing loss

questions.solution:
The image is of a digital audiometer (pure tone audiometer). A digital audiometer is a lightweight device that is portable and can be used to perform hearing tests, including pure tone audiometry. This device does not measure acoustic reflexes. 

Acoustic reflex is measured using the impedance audiometer.

An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.

Uses of pure tone audiometer:

  • To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
  • Helps to predict speech reception threshold (SRT)
  • To diagnose the type and degree of hearing loss.
  • For the prescription of hearing aids
  • Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
  • A record can be kept for future reference.

Impedance audiometry includes tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurement, which are objective tests of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing).

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text:
Match the following radiograph images with their views.
  1. Submentovertical view
  2. Caldwell view
  3. Water's view
  4. Towne's view
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a.

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Submentovertical view (also known as the basal view or Hirtz view) is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area.

 Structures seen are:
  • Sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses (seen best in that order).
  • Zygoma.
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible along with coronoid and condyloid processes.
  • External auditory canal.
  • Middle ear cleft, i.e. mastoid cells, middle ear, and eustachian tube.
  • Internal auditory canal.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: You are working as an intern in the ENT department. A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor in the child. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out in this child?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it can be ruled out in this child with biphasic stridor.

All the other options cause biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with tuberculous otitis media. Choose the correct statements regarding this condition.
  1. It is most commonly seen in children.
  2. It presents as painful foul-smelling otorrhea.
  3. Multiple perforations in tympanic membrane are seen.
  4. Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. 
  5. Reconstructive surgery is done before antitubercular therapy.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 3, and 4. Tuberculous otitis media presents as painless foul-smelling otorrhea. It is treated with a full course of antitubercular therapy followed by reconstructive surgery.

Tuberculous otitis media:

Tuberculosis of the ear usually occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis and reaches the middle ear through the eustachian tube. It occasionally spreads hematogenously, from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. Tuberculous otitis media is mostly seen in children and young adults.

It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. Patients have severe hearing loss that is out of proportion to symptoms. Although predominantly conductive, sensorineural hearing loss may also occur if the labyrinth is involved. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. 

Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, and osteomyelitis are also seen.

Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseous necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Chest X-ray features of tuberculosis along with other evidence of tuberculosis in the body help in confirmation of the diagnosis. DNA probe and PCR from the ear discharge can provide an early diagnosis.

Treatment includes:

  • Antitubercular therapy
  • Aural toilet
  • Treatment of secondary infection
  • Mastoid surgery for complications.

Reconstructive middle ear surgery is done only after the completion of antitubercular therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complete obstruction of her right nostril with a woody hard swelling of her nose as shown in the image. She gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation before the swelling appeared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting before the development a woody hard swelling in the nose is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose. (image given below)

 

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. 

Histology shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Image below shows

  • Mikulicz cells - large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli
  • Russell bodies - homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells. (noted by arrows in the image)

 

The slide given below shows Russell bodies.

 

Treatment of rhinoscleroma:

  1. Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) for a period of 4 to 6 weeks.
  2. Steroids to reduce fibrosis.
  3. Surgical intervention to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.
  4. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative. 

Other options

Option A: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as pinkish, lobulated swelling over the tip of the nose. It is associated with acne rosacea.

 

 

Option B: Atrophic rhinitis or ozaena causes atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It presents with foul smelling nasal discharge with greenish or greyish black dry crusts but doesn’t cause woody nose.

 

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by the fungus Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

The image below shows a polypoidal mass of rhinosporidiosis.

 

Image below - Histopathology of rhinosporidiosis showing several sporangia, oval, or round in shape with a chitinous wall and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its wall.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: All of the following form the boundaries of sinus lateralis of Grunwald except ___________ .
questions.solution:
The sinus lateralis of Grunwald is bounded medially by the middle turbinate, not the superior turbinate.

When there is a space above or behind the bulla ethmoidalis, it is called suprabullar or retrobullar recesses, respectively. The suprabullar and retrobullar recesses together form the lateral sinus or sinus lateralis of Grunwald. 
The lateral sinus is bounded

  • Superiorly by the skull base
  • Laterally by lamina papyracea
  • Medially by middle turbinate
  • Inferiorly by the bulla ethmoidalis
  • Posteriorly the sinus lateralis may extend up to basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

 

Note:

Inflammation in the sinus lateralis may extend anteriorly into the frontal recess or posteriorly into the posterior ethmoidal cells. Access into the sinus lateralis can be made through superior hiatus semilunaris, which is a 'sickle-shaped' cleft.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the mucous blanket of the nose?
  1. It consists of a superficial serous and a deeper mucous layer.
  2. The cilia under the blanket move at a speed of 5-10 mm/min.
  3. The complete sheet of mucus is cleared into the pharynx every 1-2 hours.
  4. The presence of turbinates doubles the surface area of the blanket.
  5. About 600-700 mL of nasal secretions are produced in 24 hours.
questions.solution:
The statements 2, 4 & 5 are correct regarding the mucous blanket of the nose.

The mucus blanket consists of a superficial mucus layer and a deeper serous layer, floating on the top of cilia, which are constantly beating to carry it like a conveyor belt towards the nasopharynx (statement 1). The mucus blanket moves at 5–10 mm/min. The complete sheet of mucus is cleared into the pharynx every 10–20 min (statement 3). The presence of turbinates doubles the surface area of the mucous blanket. About 600- 700mL of nasal secretions are produced in 24 hours.

The movement of the mucus blanket of the nose is by ciliary action. 

In mammals, cilia beat 10–20 times per second at room temperature. They have a rapid 'effective stroke' and slow 'recovery stroke'. In the former, the extended cilia reach the mucous layer while in the recovery stroke, they bend and travel slowly in the reverse direction in the thin serous layer, thus moving the mucous blanket in only one direction. 


In immotile cilia syndrome, cilia are defective and cannot beat effectively, leading to stagnation of mucus in the nose sinuses, and bronchi causing chronic rhinosinusitis and bronchiectasis. 

Movements of cilia are affected by 

  • Drying
  • Drugs (adrenaline)
  • Excessive heat or cold
  • Smoking
  • Infections
  • Noxious fumes like sulfur dioxide and carbon dioxide.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. An audible bruit is heard over mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinne test was negative.  A tumor of the middle ear is suspected. All of the following signs can be seen by otoscopy except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a woman with progressive conductive hearing loss, tinnitus and audible bruit heard over the mastoid suggests a diagnosis of a ‘glomus tumor’. The Phelp sign on CECT scan (not otoscopy) is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumors. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

The cell of origin in the glomus tumor is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumor. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

It is 5 times more common in women. Common presenting features include:

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss
  • Tinnitus in glomus tumors is pulsatile, of swishing character, synchronous with a pulse, and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Audible bruit heard over the mastoid with a stethoscope in all stages

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumor by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives the soft tissue extent of the tumor.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when the CT head shows the involvement of a jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumor.

 The below given image shows a triangular red coloured glomus tumour behind the tympanic membrane in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen
Rising sun
Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches
Phelp sign
CT
Loss of carotico-jugular crest

questions.text: A theory states that the origin of Cholesteatoma is due to the hyperplasia of basal cells of the germinal layer of skin, under the influence of infection. This theory is called _____.
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of the left tympanic membrane. This is suggestive of cholesteatoma. The theory of basal cell hyperplasia is known as ‘Ruedi’s theory’.

Cholesteatoma, also known as epidermosis or keratoma, is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in the middle ear where it is not usually present, i.e., skin in the wrong place.

The image given below shows Cholesteatoma in the left upper quadrant of this left tympanic membrane.

Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types:

  • congenital
  • acquired

Congenital cholesteatoma can be explained by the presence of congenital cells that rests within the middle ear and other parts of the temporal bone.

Acquired cholesteatoma is explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and Eustachian tube drainage or the tympanic membrane epithelium.

The theories put forth are given in the pearl that follows:

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old diabetic patient has come to you with excruciating right ear pain and right-sided facial palsy. Otoscopic examination of the ear shows granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Choose the correct statements regarding this condition.
  1. It is a malignant condition.
  2. It can occur in immunocompromised patients.
  3. Technetium 99 scan is used to monitor the disease.
  4. Gallium-67 scan is useful in the follow-up of the patient.
  5. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is given.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of an elderly diabetic patient with excruciating ear pain, facial palsy, and granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal point toward the diagnosis of malignant otitis externa. The correct statements are 2, 4 and 5.

Malignant otitis externa is an infective condition (not malignant). Technetium 99 scan is not used to monitor the disease. 

Malignant otitis externa/ Necrotizing otitis externa:

It is an inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised patients. It is characterised by excruciating ear pain, profuse discharge and granulations on the floor of the external ear canal.

Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.

Gallium-67 scan is useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Treatment includes:

  • Control of diabetes.
  • Toilet of the ear canal. Remove discharge, debris and granulations or at dead tissue or bone.
  • Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa for 6-8 weeks or more. If the patient is not responsive, treatment should be based on culture and sensitivity of ear discharge.

Antibiotics which are usually effective against pseudomonas aeroginosa are:

  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (IV)
  • Third-generation cephalosporins (IV) e.g. ceftriaxone, ceftazidime along with an aminoglycoside
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin and levofloxacin) combined with rifampin (Oral)

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ENT department and assisting with mastoidectomy surgery. The surgeon asks you about the landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. All of the following are boundaries of that landmark except?

choices.text: Posterosuperior segment of bony external auditory canal
Tangent drawn to external auditory canal

questions.solution:
MacEwen’s triangle(suprameatal triangle) is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery. Processus cochleariformis does not form the boundary of the suprameatal triangle.

 Boundaries of MacEwen’s (suprameatal) triangle:

  • Superior- temporal line
  • Anterior-  posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal
  • Posterior- the line drawn as a tangent to the external canal.

Image showing the suprameatal triangle:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to you with impaction of the fishbone in the area which forms the lateral channel for food. All of the following form the boundaries of this area except?
questions.solution:
The given scenario represents the impaction of fishbone in the pyriform fossa, which forms the lateral channel for food. The pyriform fossa is not bounded medially by the cuneiform cartilage.

Pyriform fossa:

It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It is bounded laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, posterolateral surfaces of arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. 

The internal laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and this is easily accessible for local anesthesia. It is also through this nerve that the pain is referred to as the ear in the carcinoma of the pyriform sinus.

Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of lymph nodes. The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain. 

The image below shows a cut section of the human larynx. Note the location of the pyriform fossa/sinus.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is examining a child as a part of a routine health check-up. Her otoscopic findings are given in the image below. Which of the following is not true regarding the structure marked by the arrow?

choices.text: It has a thin fibrous layer
Situated above the lateral process of malleus
Its periphery is called annulus tympanicus
It is also called Shrapnell’s membrane

questions.solution:
The image shows a normal tympanic membrane and the part marked in the image is pars flaccida. The statement C about annulus tympanicus is wrong. Annulus tympanicus is a part of pars tensa, not pars flaccida.

The normal tympanic membrane is shiny and pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent. It is concave to the external auditory canal with the maximum concavity at the umbo.

Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane. It has a thin fibrous layer and appears slightly pinkish. It is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the anterior and posterior malleal folds and the notch of Rivinus. 

Pars tensa forms most of the tympanic membrane. In the peripheral region, pars tensa forms a thick fibrocartilaginous structure called annulus tympanicus. The central part of pars tensa is indented inwards at the tip of the malleus and is known as the umbo. A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the umbo to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. 

Invagination of the tympanic membrane either to pars tensa or pars flaccida results in retraction pockets.

Tos classification: This is used to grade the retraction in pars flaccida or attic retraction

  • Stage 1: The pars flaccida is dimpled but not in touch with the malleus.
  • Stage 2: The tympanic membrane is in contact with the neck of malleus and the entire extent of retraction can be visualized.
  • Stage 3: The retraction is not visible fully, and there may be partial erosion of bony attic wall. 
  • Stage 4: The retraction is definite erosion of the bony attic wall and the full extent of retraction is not visible.

Due to difficulty in distinguishing the latter two, it is grouped as stage 3/4.

Sade classification: This is used to grade the retraction in pars tensa

  • Stage 1: The tympanic membrane is retracted but not in touch with the incus
  • Stage 2: The tympanic membrane is in contact with the long process of the incus
  • Stage 3: Middle ear atelectasis - the tympanic membrane is in contact with the promontory, but not adherent. It can be raised from the promontory with suction
  • Stage 4: Adhesive otitis media - the tympanic membrane is adherent to the promontory

Related Pearl: Tympanic membrane

Parts of the tympanic membrane

Pars Tensa
Pars Flaccida
Taut
Loose
Middle fibrous layer is well organized
Middle fibrous layer is not well organized
Contains annulus tympanicus
 Also called Shrapnell’s membrane
Transmits sound
Does not transmit sound

Layers of the tympanic membrane

  Outer Middle Inner
Layer Epithelium Fibrous Mucosa
Continuous with Skin of EAC - Middle ear mucosa
Derived from Ectoderm Mesoderm Endoderm
