questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of recurrent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and declining scholastic performance. An X-ray is done which is shown below. Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing enlarged adenoids are suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia aperta(Hypernasality) would not be seen in this condition, but rhinolalia clausa(Hyponasality) would be seen instead.

Adenoids also known as nasopharyngeal tonsils are prone to physiological enlargement during childhood. Affected children typically present with symptoms of nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, sinusitis, and rhinolalia clausa (loss of nasal tone of voice). They may also experience aprosexia (inability to concentrate) leading to declining scholastic performance. These children have characteristic adenoid facies marked by a dull expression, open mouth, pinched in nose, high arched palate, and crowded upper teeth. 

When symptoms are bothersome, it is removed by adenoidectomy. Otherwise, decongestant nasal drops and antihistamines can be used.

Indications for adenoidectomy:

  • Symptoms like snoring, mouth breathing, and rhinolalia clausa due to adenoid hypertrophy
  • Recurrent ear discharge
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion secondary to adenoid hyperplasia

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft/ submucous palate: Adenoidectomy leads to velopharyngeal insufficiency in these cases and may cause rhinolalia aperta.
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Active local infection

Given below are the conditions with rhinolalia clausa and rhinolalia aperta:

Rhinolalia clausa
(Hyponasality)		 Rhinolalia aperta
(Hypernasality)
Common cold Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Nasal allergy Congenitally short soft palate
Nasal polypi Submucous palate
Nasal growth Large nasopharynx
Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate
Nasopharyngeal mass Paralysis of the soft palate
Familial speech pattern Post adenoidectomy
Habitual Oronasal fistula
  Familial speech pattern
  Habitual

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to you with complaints of pain over the nose after falling from height. On examination, there is a fracture of the nasal septum. Which of the following instruments would you use during the surgery for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of nasal septum fracture. The instrument used during surgery for this condition is Asch forceps as seen in the image 2.

Other options:

Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

Option D: Citelli’s forceps is used for bone punch.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought by her mother with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. Her voice was thick and dull. All of the following can cause unilateral nasal obstruction except?
questions.solution:
All of the given conditions can cause unilateral nasal obstruction, except atrophic rhinitis which causes bilateral nasal obstruction.

Causes of unilateral nasal obstruction:

  • Vestibule:
    • Stenosis of nares
    • Atresia
    • Naso alveolar cyst
    • Papilloma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Nasal cavity:
    • Foreign body
    • Deviated nasal septum (DNS)
    • Hypertrophic turbinates
    • Concha bullosa
    • Antrochoanal polyp
    • Rhinolith
    • Benign and malignant tumors of the nose and paranasal sinuses
    • Sinusitis, unilateral
  •  Nasopharynx:
    • Unilateral choanal atresia

Causes of bilateral nasal obstruction:

  • Vestibule:
    • Collapsing nasal alae
    • Stenosis of nares
    • Congenital atresia of nares
  • Nasal cavity:
    • Acute rhinitis (viral and bacterial)
    • Chronic rhinitis and sinusitis
    • Rhinitis medicamentosa
    • Allergic rhinitis
    • Hypertrophic turbinates
    • DNS
    • Nasal polypi
    • Atrophic rhinitis
    • Rhinitis sicca
    • Septal hematoma
    • Bilateral choanal atresia
  • Nasopharynx:
    • Adenoid hyperplasia 
    • Large choanal polyp
    • Thornwaldt’s cyst
    • Large benign and malignant tumours

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy diagnosed with tonsillitis complains of referred pain in the ears. Which of the following nerves is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

Image below shows the anatomic relations of tonsil and tonsillar bed.

The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3).

Jacobson's nerve along with branches from the sympathetic plexus forms the tympanic plexus. This plexus provides sensation to the middle ear, upper eustachian tube, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane.

Referred otalgia transmitted by the glossopharyngeal nerve may be secondary to lesions and/or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate, or posterior one-third of the tongue.

Causes of referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Acute pharyngitis
  • Tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess
  • Post-tonsillectomy
  • Foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area
  • Elongated styloid process

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

  Head and neck Body position
Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text: Which of the following arteries supplies the Kisselbach’s plexus and is derived from the internal carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Anterior ethmoidal artery supplies the Kisselbach’s plexus and is derived from the internal carotid artery via its ophthalmic branch.

Arterial supply of the nasal septum:

Internal carotid system

  • Branches of the ophthalmic artery
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery
    • Posterior ethmoidal artery

External carotid system

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery).

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum (Little's area) to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of the superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

Little's area is the most common site for epistaxis in children and young adults.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.  It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals.

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis.

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus. 

The local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge is typically seen in invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

A definitive diagnosis is done with a biopsy and histopathologic examination. It is the most sensitive and specific method. It reveals aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles. 

Among the imaging techniques used for diagnosis, MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice. 1,3 beta D- glucan assay, which is helpful for the identification of most fungi, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Management is by amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues. The underlying cause and risk factors should also be addressed.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents as nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuses such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

Small vocal nodules are treated conservatively with speech therapy. Large ones are treated by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

questions.text: A patient who underwent septoplasty, complains of pressure over the nose and difficulty in breathing on postoperative day 1. Local examination revealed smooth, round, soft, and fluctuant swellings on either side of the septum. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient with clinical features suggestive of septal hematoma is incision and drainage. 

Septal hematoma refers to a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery (as in this patient), or spontaneously in bleeding disorders.

Patients usually present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, smooth, round swellings, soft and fluctuant on palpation, can be seen on either side of the septum.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. A small anteroposterior incision is made parallel to the nasal floor. It must be followed by nasal packing. Smaller hematomas can be aspirated using a wide gauge needle. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. 

CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion.

Treatment: Endoscopic surgical drainage and ventilation along with systemic steroids.

Other options:

Option B: Ethmoidal polyps are multiple and bilateral and arise from the lateral wall of the nose. Patients are mostly adults and present with bilateral nasal obstruction, anosmia/ hyposmia, sneezing, rhinorrhea, and a polypoidal mass from the nostril.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus,

Option D: Nasoethmoidal carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, diplopia, lateral displacement of the eyeball, broadening of nasal root, and retro-orbital pain.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient previously treated for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with similar symptoms. Radio-imaging confirms a recurrence with an inaccessible intracranial extension. Which of the following treatment approaches is considered now?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is considered for recurrent inaccessible juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

JNA is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with:

  • Epistaxis (most common presentation): Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous
  • Mass: A mass may be present in either the postnasal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed.
  • Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves: May occur

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

 

Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery or radiotherapy when the tumor is inaccessible.

Other options:

Option A: Hormonal therapy can be used as primary or adjunctive treatment. Since it is commoner in adolescent males in their twenties, the tumor may be testosterone dependant. Therefore, hormonal therapy with diethylstilbestrol and an androgen blocker like flutamide may be considered.

Option B: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option C: Endoscopic approach is not useful as the stem clearly mentions that the tumor is inaccessible.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. He struggles to hear and understand speech despite appropriately fit hearing aids. The ENT specialist decided that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. What is the site in which the electrode is placed?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway a prerequisites for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing for 2 months. He mentions that he is taking hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He works at a cement manufacturing factory. Otoscopy findings are normal. Rinne’s test result is positive in both ears. Audiometry results are shown below. What is the likely cause of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
The pure-tone audiogram shown in the given image shows an acoustic dip at 4000 Hz, which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. 

The patient's employment history (working at a cement factory) suggests constant exposure to loud noise. Positive Rinne's test result in both ears suggests that air conduction is better than bone conduction, i.e. absence of conductive hearing loss or presence of sensorineural hearing loss.

Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120–155 dB, such as explosions and gunshots, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Other options:

Option A: Medication adverse effects (ototoxicity) cause bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics, loop diuretics (not thiazides), antimalarials, cisplatin, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Pure-tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz, which is known as Carhart's notch. There is a loss of air conduction in the lower frequencies.

The audiogram given below shows Carhart's notch, which is seen in otosclerosis.

Option D: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

World Hearing Day is celebrated on March 3, 2022. Globally, over one billion people are at risk of hearing loss due to loud volumes for long periods. Hearing loss caused by loud sounds is permanent; however, it is also completely preventable. The theme for this year's campaign is "To hear for life, listen with care"

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm).

It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis.

Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.

Related Pearl: Measurements of EAC and ET

 

External Auditory Canal

Eustachian tube

Total length

24 mm

36 mm

Bony (close to the middle ear)

16 mm (2/3)

12 mm (1/3)

Cartilaginous

8 mm (1/3)

24 mm (2/3)

Isthmus (narrowest part)

In the bony part

At the junction

questions.text: A nasogastric tube could not be passed in a newborn having cyclical hypoxia. There is an absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge and there was no misting on a metal spatula under the nose. Which of the following is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of choanal atresia, and McGovern’s technique is an effective substitute for tracheostomy in this condition.

Choanal atresia is characterised by a persistent bucco-nasal membrane, leaving a sheet of tissue at the back of the nose and separating it from the pharynx.

Features of choanal atresia include: 

  • Cyclical hypoxia: This is observed in the newborn, where the baby cries, taking in air through the mouth. This relieves the hypoxia, but upon settling down for a while and closing its mouth, the baby struggles to breathe and becomes hypoxic again.
  • Presence of mucoid nasal discharge
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Absence of misting on a cold metal spatula held under the nose

Choanal atresia can be confirmed by putting methylene blue dye into the nose and observing its passage to the pharynx or putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph. The most useful investigation though is an axial CT scan.

Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by transpalatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at 1.5 years of age.

McGovern's technique involves the use of a feeding nipple with a large hole, which provides a good oral airway in the infant, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Trotter’s method is used to control epistaxis. The patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood, and breathe quietly from the mouth, as shown in the image below.

 

Option C: Epley’s manoeuvre is used in the treatment of Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo, as shown in the image below.

 

Option D: Pringle maneuver is used to minimize blood loss during hepatic surgery by clamping the vascular pedicle (free margin of lesser omentum), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.solution:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS (cold–opposite, warm–same). 

The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it and the nystagmus is horizontal.  

The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram.

If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is incus.

This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes.

CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
BERA, OAE, and tympanometry are the objective tests for hearing. PTA (pure tone audiometry) is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on patient responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured. 

The image below shows the types of tympanogram:

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 60-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling is reducible in the neck and increases in size on coughing and performing the Valsalva maneuver. The given presentation is due to an enlarged diverticulum in ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests laryngocele, and it occurs due to the abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx).

Ventricle/Sinus of the larynx:

It is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds. The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane, which starts from the anterior part of the ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When abnormally enlarged and distended, the saccule may form a laryngocele—an air-containing sac that may present in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. Laryngocele in adults may be associated with carcinoma. 

CT scan helps in assessing the extent of the lesion.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization, and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

 

Other options:

Option A: The vestibule is the upper portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the laryngeal inlet and the vestibular folds. It is related to the posterior surface of epiglottis anteriorly, aryepiglottic folds laterally, and the anterior surface of arytenoids posteriorly.

Option C: The infraglottic larynx (subglottic space) is the lower portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. Histologically, it is the transition zone between the stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords and the respiratory epithelium of the trachea.

Option D: Rima glottidis (glottis) is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity measuring 24 mm in men and 16 mm in women anteroposteriorly. It is present between the two vocal cords. Anterior two-thirds of the glottis, known as phonatory glottis, is formed by membranous cords, while the posterior one-third, known as respiratory glottis, is formed by the vocal processes of arytenoids.

The image given below shows the glottis.

Related Pearl: Sites and subsites of the larynx (AJCC Classification)

Sites

Subsites

Supraglottis

Aryepiglottic folds with the corniculate and cuneiform cartilages

Image :  A top view of the larynx (seen with a mirror).

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher comes to you with complaints of dryness, tightness, and soreness in the throat. He says these symptoms appear after long hours of talking in class. He is also unable to hold long conversations. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is his possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter arytenoid muscles are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of discharge from the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo syndrome. 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. Patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a case of otitis media?
questions.solution:
Battle sign refers to retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the temporal bone. Battle sign is not seen in the case of otitis media.

Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck. 

Option B: Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

Option D: Delta sign is a contrast-enhanced CT finding seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis, which can occur as a complication of acute mastoiditis or chronic suppurative otitis media. It is a triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior cranial fossa on axial cuts. MR venography is useful to assess the progression or resolution of a thrombus. 

The image below depicts a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sagittal sinus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with progressive conductive hearing loss was found to have otosclerotic foci on the entire footplate along with complete involvement of the oval window. What type of otosclerosis is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
The otosclerotic foci found on the entire footplate of stapes along with complete involvement of the oval window is an obliterative type of stapedial otosclerosis.

The stapedial type of otosclerosis presents predominantly with a bilateral conductive type of deafness and can be of various types:

  • Anterior focus: Involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
  • Posterior focus: Only fissula post fenestrum
  • Circumferential: Around the margin of the stapes footplate
  • Biscuit type: Entire footplate except for the annular ligament
  • Obliterative: Entire footplate when it completely obliterates the oval window niche.

Otosclerosis is a bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. This condition worsens during stress and conditions with hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis Any site but asymptomatic

 

Clinical features

  • An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.
  • In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The image below shows the Schwartze sign.

  • Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).
  • Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch. 

The image below shows Carhart's notch in pure tone audiometry. 

  • Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicating that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. 

The image below shows As type of curve in tympanometry which is seen in otosclerosis.

  • As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Image below shows stapedotomy procedure.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient with middle ear fluid accumulation is tested using tympanometry. What is the expected tympanogram finding seen in this case?

choices.text: Compliance is high at or near ambient air pressure
Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure
Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of middle ear fluid accumulation, the expected tympanogram finding would be a flat or dome-shaped graph.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are obtained. They are as follows:

The image given below shows impedance audiometry. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in the external auditory canal

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: In a 35-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident with facial injuries, radiological investigations show a complete separation between the facial bones and the cranial bones. What type of Le-Fort's classification is associated with this pattern of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing complete separation of facial and cranial bones is suggestive of Le-Fort III maxillary fracture. It signifies craniofacial disjunction.

Clinical features include malocclusion of teeth, elongation of the midface, mobility in the maxilla, and CSF rhinorrhoea.

Diagnosis is made with x-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan.

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort III fracture.

 

The image below shows the fracture line in Le-Fort I fracture.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort II fracture.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A young boy presents with fever and pain while swallowing. He is also noticed to have a typical hot potato voice and drooling of saliva. The following finding is seen on oral examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing congested tonsil, pillar, and soft palate on the right side with a swollen and oedematous uvula pushed to the opposite side is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It is a complication of tonsillitis.

The clinical features include sore throat, dysphagia, odynophagia, hot potato voice, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever. On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

It is treated with intravenous antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess. An interval tonsillectomy is done after 4-6 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Tonsillitis occurs due to bacterial infection of the faucial tonsils. Patients present with a sore throat, dysphagia, ear pain, and constitutional symptoms. Tonsils are enlarged and congested with/ without a membrane or yellowish spots over the tonsil.

The image below shows tonsillitis:

Option B: Adenoiditis refers to the infection of the nasopharyngeal tonsil that occurs due to repeated attacks of rhinitis, sinusitis, or tonsillitis in children. The patients present with nasal obstruction, and mouth breathing. The patients have characteristic adenoid facies i.e. elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, high arched hard palate, hitched up upper lip, prominent and crowded upper teeth. 

The images below show enlarged adenoids and adenoid facies respectively. 

Option D: Parotid abscess is the suppuration of the parotid space most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is seen in the postoperative period, dehydration, and debilitated patients. Patients appear toxic with swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness in the parotid gland and at the angle of the mandible. 

The image below shows a parotid abscess.

questions.text: A transgender person who has undergone a gender transformation from male to female would like to sound more like a female. Which of the following phonosurgeries would be advised in this case?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the vocal cords is the phonosurgery to elevate the voice pitch which transforms male character voice to female.

If someone who has undergone gender transformation from female to male would like to lower the voice pitch, a phono surgery involving shortening/relaxation of the vocal cord is advised.

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

I

Medialization

In complete palsy (superior and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy)

II

Lateralization

In recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

III

Shortening (relax the vocal cord)

To reduce pitch

IV

Lengthening (tighten the vocal cord)

To increase pitch

Note to remember: MLSL

questions.text: A 19-year-old drummer presented with complaints of difficulty in hearing and severe pain in the left ear. Otoscopic examination revealed impacted wax with pearly white keratinous debris in the external auditory canal. Audiometry revealed a conductive hearing loss. Which of the following complications is least likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Exposure and damage to the facial nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, with pearly white keratin debris in the external auditory canal, suggests the diagnosis of keratosis obturans. Narrowing of the meatus is the least likely complication, as this condition is associated with widening of the meatus.

Due to the pressure effect by desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus, there is subsequent absorption of surrounding bone, leading to the widening of the meatus. Sometimes, the extent of bone absorption is such that it leaves the facial nerve exposed to injury and subsequent paralysis. Extensive erosion of the bone can also result in automastoidectomy.

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Conventionally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of or any obstruction to this migration caused by wax impacted in the ear canal may lead to keratosis obturans.

It is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. The keratin that is shed from the entire circumference of the deep ear canal appears to have an onion skin arrangement. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytics such as 2% salicylic acid in alcohol.

Note: Narrowing refers to a decrease in the diameter of the meatus. Debris in kerotosis obturans or ear wax might cause obstruction (partial or complete) but does not cause narrowing. Narrowing of the meatus is seen in conditions such as ear canal stenosis.
